snippet: Even with the demand for seats increasing, the big airlines have not restored many of their flights, particularly on routes to small airports.
abstract: Airlines seeking to bolster profits are cutting back service to small and midsize airports, even with the demand for seats increasing, leaving passengers with longer and more complicated flight schedules; trips that may have taken a couple of hours on a nonstop flight a few years ago are often daylong journeys involving multiple flights and lots of waiting. Photos, Graph, Maps (M)
lead_paragraph: It took Josh Hunter three separate planes, two connections and a two-hour drive to get from Mobile, Ala., to Cincinnati at Easter. When he added it all up, his 720-mile trip had lasted 12 hours -- about the same it would have taken him to drive. ''The whole point of flying should be to save a lot of time, and I didn't,'' Mr. Hunter said.

headline.main: Flying Between Smaller Cities Is Becoming a Marathon Sport
